abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and its institutional development
            impact is substantial. Debates on the economic policy in
            transition economies question the merits of a "big
            bang" approach, relative to a more gradual strategy,
            the argument being that incentive reforms - in the absence
            of institutional reforms - will create new distortions, with
            an unlikely sustainability. However, a lesson supported by
            this project, mainly exemplified by the project's
            reform program, seem to indicate that under the right
            conditions, the big bang may prove effective, for it was not
            until the Government took decisive action on a stabilization
            program based on a currency board, along with an ambitious
            structural adjustment program, that the country initiated a
            market economy approach, with a seemingly accelerated
            economic growth. Further lessons suggest the value of
            constructive disengagement in a poor policy environment.
            Since the Bank was not associated with the old regime, it
            was thus well positioned to engage, and support the new
            Government, moving quickly through the Critical Imports
            Rehabilitation Loan, once it was clear reforms would be
            taken seriously. Additionally, the value of good sector work
            laid the foundations for successful lending operations, and
            extensive dialogue supported the conditions for the project success.
